doc.field: The Albert Memorial commemorates Prince Albert of Saxe-Coburg-Gotha (1819-1861), Consort of Queen Victoria (1840-1861) and is an elaborate canopied monument embellished with gilt, mosaic and coloured stones. A central bronze seated figure of Prince Albert, represented in the robes of the Garter and holding in his right hand a catalogue of the Great Exhibition of 1851, is situated under a Gothic spire. The pedestal stands on a raised platform approached by flights of steps on four sides, at the corners of the pedestal, at the base of the clustered granite columns, are marble allegorical groups representing Agriculture, Manufactures, Commerce and Engineering. Around the pedestal are reliefs of 169 poets, painters, sculptors, architects and musicians. At the base of the steps are groups representing the Continents-Europe, Asia, Africa and America. The inscription reads “Queen Victoria And Her people- To the memory of Albert Prince Consort- As A Tribute Of Their Gratitude - For A Life Devoted To The Public Good.” In the mosaics “Music” is represented on the south face in flowing robes of crimson and gold, and bearing in the right hand a Welsh harp in green. The east tablet represents “Painting”, and the figure is picked out in dark green, with palette and brushes in the left hand. “Sculpture” is represented on the west panel, with the emblematical figure in blue; and on the north “Architecture” is symbolized, the majestic figure being draped in deep crimson. The memorial was designed by Sir George Gilbert Scott. Various sculptors worked on the memorial: 1.John Foley worked on the figure of Prince Albert. 2. The group “Europe” was the work of Patrick Macdowell. 3. The group “Asia” was by John Foley. 4. The group “Africa” was the work of William Theed 5. The group “America” was the work of John Bell 6. The marble allegorical group “Agriculture” was the work of W.Calder Marshall 7. The marble allegorical group “Manufactures” was the work of Henry Weekes 8. The marble allegorical group “Commerce” was the work of Thomas Thornycroft 9. The marble allegorical group “Engineering” was the work of John Lawlor 10. Of the 169 portrait figures the Poets and musicians on the South Front and the painters on the east Front were the work of H.H.Armstead and the architects on the North Front and the sculptors on the West front were the work of J.B.Philip. 11. Armstead and Philip were also responsible for the eight statues representing the practical arts and sciences on the plllars and in the niches of the canopy. Armstead worked on those on the eastern side and Philip on those on the western side,. The four “Christian” and four “moral” virtues in the aedicular stage of the fleche were modelled by James Redfern. The two tiers of angels in the upper stages of the fleche were modelled by J.B.Philip. The fleche itself was made by F.A.Skidmore. The architectural stone-carving was carried out by William Brindley The erection of the memorial was started in 1864 and opened to the public in 1872. The unveiling took place on 9th March 1876.
The composition Agriculture on the Albert Memorial

This memorial stands as a tribute to Albert I. It shows the King astride his horse within a crown raised on ten columns. From this memorial we can see the present day Yser sluice gates. It was their 1914 counterparts which were opened in October 1914. The memorial was designed by Julien de Ridder and inaugurated on the 24th July 1938.

Albert Toft was the sculptor of the War Memorial at Stone in Staffordshire which stands in Granville Square. It features a bareheaded soldier in uniform who stands on a pedestal with bowed head and arms reversed. It has been said that the soldier seems to be musing on those killed in the war. At his feet is a helmet. On the four sides of the pedestal are bronze plaques with the names of the dead. Those relating to the men killed in the second World War have Staffordshire knots at their bases. The Stone War Memorial was unveiled by the Earl of Dartmouth on the 10th January 1921.

The sculptor Albert Toft carved the four statues around the exterior of the Hall of Memory in Birmingham.They represent the Army, Navy, Air Force, and Women’s Services. The Hall of Memory is in Centenary Square in the centre of Birmingham.The Hall of Memory features an octagonal hall with a domed roof. It is built of Portland stone on a Cornish granite plinth. Inside books of remembrance are contained within a glass case. There are also three relief panels showing war scenes. The relief panels are by William Bloye Toft’s figures are allegorical figures representing:- The Navy. The bare-chested sailor is crouching and holds a coil of rope in one hand and the wheel of a ship in the other. The Army. A bare-chested soldier is also crouching and rests his right hand on the barrel of a machine gun. The Air Force. A bare-chested figure crouches and holds the blade and aerlions of an aircraft in his left hand. The Nursing Service. A woman crouches down whilst holding a wreath in her left hand with arm outstretched. In this photograph we see the figure representing the Air Force.

The Welsh memorial to the fallen of the South African War at the south end of King Edward VII Avenue in Cardiff. This memorial was unveiled by General Sir John French on 20th November 1909. The standing figure is Peace bearing an olive tree. There are two seated figures on either side of the central plinth and that of the woman, on the north-east side, represents "Grief" and holds a wreath in her left hand. This is a photograph of that seated woman
South African War Memorial in Cardiff

The Sandon Hall War Memorial was unveiled on the 7th May 1921 and remembers the men of the Sandon Hall Estate who lost their lives in the 1914-1918 war. A soldier on a plinth stands at ease with his rifle held in his right hand and his left hand clenched in a fist. He has a determined look on his face. This memorial was unveiled on the 7th May 1921 by Colonel John Ward DSO MP. The bronze plaques carry a good deal of detail and are shown in the gallery below. One carries details of the actual date of death and where that death occurred; something that is I think quite rare. The sculptor was Albert Toft.
